As of February 1, 2023, employees will acquire a fourth day, and will continue to accumulate one day a month up to a maximum of 10 days per year.
Effective December 18, 2022, Canada’s Employment Insurance sickness benefits were extended from 15 weeks to 26 weeks. As such, qualified individuals who establish a new claim on or after December 18, 2022 will receive up to 26 weeks of Employment Insurance sickness benefits, paid at 55% of their average weekly insurance earnings, for up to a maximum of $650 per week in 2023.

Maternity leave may not begin before the 17th week preceding the expected delivery date and shall end not later than 18 weeks after. If the delivery occurs after the expected date, the employee is entitled to at least two additional weeks of maternity leave. Special maternity leave may begin four weeks before the expected delivery date when there is a risk of termination of her pregnancy or a danger for the health of the mother or unborn child caused by the pregnancy. Two weeks’ notice and a medical certificate is required.

Sick leave entitlement in Alberta depends on whether the employee falls under provincial or federal regulation, and whether they qualify for Employment Insurance (EI) sickness benefits.
Regulated workers under the Alberta Employment Standard Code are entitled to 5 days of unpaid job protected Personal & Family Responsibility Leave per year. This can be taken if the worker is ill or for the employee to meet a need of family member. Employees must have completed 90 days of employment to be eligible. Unused days do not carryover into the next calendar year. An employee must give an employer notice as soon as is reasonable before taking this leave. More details and eligibility criteria can be found on the Government of Alberta website.
Federally regulated workers are entitled under the Canada Labour Code to receive up to 10 days paid sick leave per year. These 10 days paid sick leave is accrued during the year after an initial 30-day qualifying period of continuous employment has been completed.  Following this qualifying period, workers earn the first 3 days of paid medical leave. Following this, workers earn 1 further day of paid sick leave at the start of each month after completing 1 month of continuous employment until a maximum of 10 days paid sick leave per year has been accrued. Any days of medical leave with pay that are not taken within the year will be carried over to the beginning of the new year up to a maximum of 10 days. More details and eligibility criteria can be found on the Government of Canada website.
Regardless of jurisdiction, workers may also qualify for Employment Insurance (EI) sickness benefits, which are administered federally. These benefits are available to employees who are unable to work due to medical reasons and meet the eligibility criteria. EI sickness benefits provide 55% of average weekly earnings, up to 695 CAD per week, for a maximum of 26 weeks. To qualify, employees typically need 600 insured hours worked in the 52 weeks prior to illness and must submit a medical certificate. More information can be found on the Government of Canada website.
Maternity Leave
In Canada, Maternity and Parental leave rights are set out through the nationwide Employment Insurance (EI) program, which is applied across all provinces and entitles eligible mothers to take up to 15 weeks of maternity leave with income support. For Federally regulated employees and industries, up to 17 weeks maternity leave can be taken. During this period, eligible employees will receive maternity benefits equal to 55% of their earnings, up to a maximum of 695 CAD per week. To receive this benefit, workers must provide a certificate from a healthcare practitioner confirming the pregnancy. For further guidance and eligibility criteria, refer to the Government of Canada website.
In addition to EI, each individual province sets their own set of employment standards that determine the full available leave entitlements for parents.
In Alberta, mothers are entitled to take a maximum of 16 consecutive weeks maternity leave providing they have completed at least 90 days of employment before maternity leave begins. The earliest this leave can be taken is 13 weeks before the due date. There is no additional requirement for employers to provide pay during this leave unless specifically stated in the employment contract or Collective Agreement. Any other pay entitlement will be through the EI. Employees must give employers written notice at least 6 weeks before starting Maternity leave. More information and eligibility criteria can be found on the Alberta Government website.
Following the completion of the maternity benefits, mothers can go on to take Parental Leave.

leave.other_leave:
Bereavement Leave
This leave is in place for workers whose family member has died. There are two support systems; the system that applies depends on if the worker falls under a federally regulated sector or under the provincial sector:
Workers regulated under the Alberta Employment Standards Code are entitled to 3 days per year of unpaid job protected leave in the event of the death of a family member. To be eligible, workers must have at least 90 days of continuous service.
Federally regulated workers under the Canada Labour Code are entitled to up to 10 days of job protected bereavement leave following the death of an immediate family member. This leave can be taken within 6 weeks of the death. The first 3 days of this leave will be paid if the worker has completed 3 months of continuous employment.
Compassionate Care Leave
This leave is in place for workers who need to care for gravely-ill family members, with significant risk of dying. There are two support systems in place which can both be applied to workers:
Under Canada’s Federal Employment Insurance (EI), eligible employees who have at least 600 insured hours of work in the 52 weeks before the start of the claim or since the start of their last claim (whichever is shorter) is entitled to caregiving leave of up to 26 weeks. There might also be eligibility for income support equal to 55% of earnings, up to a maximum of 695 CAD per week.
Under the Alberta Employments Standard Code, eligible employees who have been employed for at least 90 days can take up to 27 weeks of leave to care for gravely-ill family members (which exceeds the EI leave length by one week). Employees must give their employer a medical certificate for the ill family member and, where possible, must give written notice at least 2 weeks before the start date of their leave.  Notice must include the estimated date of the employee’s return to work. This leave is unpaid, but workers might still be eligible to receive income support under the EI.
Long-term Illness & Injury Leave
This leave is in place for workers who need to take time off for leave due to illness, injury or quarantine. There are two support systems in place which can both be applied to workers:
Under the Alberta Employments Standard Code, eligible employees who have been employed for at least 90 days can take up to 16 weeks of job protected long-term illness or injury leave per year. Employees must give their employer a doctors note and provide written notice of leave as soon as is reasonable, which must include the estimated return to work date. Employees must provide at least 1 week’s written notice of the date they intend to return to work unless there is an agreement otherwise. This leave is unpaid, but workers might still be eligible to receive income support under the EI.
Under Canada’s Federal Employment Insurance (EI), eligible employees who have at least 600 insured hours of work in the 52 weeks before the start of the claim or since the start of their last claim (whichever is shorter) is entitled to sickness leave of up to 26 weeks. There might also be eligibility for income support equal to 55% of earnings, up to a maximum of 695 CAD per week.
Additional Leave
Under the Canada Labour Code and Alberta Employments Standard Code other types of leave are also regulated including Reservist Leave, Jury Leave, Domestic Violence Leave and Death or Disappearance of a Child Leave.

Six weeks’ notice is required if the employee is within the eighth year of service up to the tenth year of service.
Eight weeks’ notice is required if the employee has been employed for ten years or more.

Payroll Cycle

An employer has 1 month to remit an employee’s first pay. After this, wages must be paid at regular intervals that are no less frequent than semi-monthly (i.e. at least twice per month). However, where there is written agreement with the employee, it is permissible to pay wages on a monthly basis. If a scheduled payday falls on a statutory holiday, wages must be paid on the last working day prior to the holiday.

working_hours.general_info:
General

A full-time workweek is 40 hours, 8 hours per day. The Labour Standards Code states that under normal circumstances employers must grant employees a rest period of at least 24 consecutive hours in every 7 days. Specific industries are regulated by different working hours, as outlined in the Code.

Overtime

Employees are entitled to receive a rate of 150% of their regular wage for each hour worked after 48 hours in a week.

Certain industries are characterized by irregular working hours and conditions and do not follow the general rule. Some have special rules about overtime and some others are not covered by overtime, as outlined in the Code.

Annual Leave (vacation)

In Nova Scotia, under the Labour Standards Code, employees are entitled to vacation time based on their length of continuous employment with the same employer:

Up to the ninth year of employment = 2 weeks of vacation after each 12-month vacation entitlement year and must give the vacation time within 10 months following the 12-month earning period.
From the ninth year of service (having completed 8 years) = 3 weeks of vacation annually.

Employees are also entitled to vacation pay based on service length:

Up to the eight year of employment = vacation pay must be at least 4% of the gross wages earned in the 12-month vacation entitlement year.
From the eighth year of service (having completed 7 years) = vacation pay must be at least 6% of the gross wages.

Public Holidays

There are 6 public holidays in Nova Scotia. If the holiday falls on the employee’s regular day off, the employer must give the employee a different day off with pay.

Employees that work on a public holiday are paid 150% of their regular hourly salary rate.

Sick Days

Sick leave entitlement in Nova Scotia depends on whether the employee falls under provincial or federal regulation, and whether they qualify for Employment Insurance (EI) sickness benefits.

Under Nova Scotia’s Employment Standards, sick leave of up to 5 days unpaid leave per year is available for personal illness or injury. An additional 3 unpaid days off are also available under the Family Responsibility leave (see below) which employees can instead use for personal medical, dental or other similar appointments. Employers can only request a medical note if the employee has missed more than five consecutive working days due to sickness or the employee has already had at least two non-consecutive absences of five or fewer days due to sickness or injury in the preceding 12-month period. More information can be found on the Nova Scotia Government website.
Federally regulated workers are entitled under the Canada Labour Code to receive up to 10 days paid sick leave per year. These 10 days paid sick leave is accrued during the year after an initial 30-day qualifying period of continuous employment has been completed.  Following this qualifying period, workers earn the first 3 days of paid medical leave. Following this, workers earn 1 further day of paid sick leave at the start of each month after completing 1 month of continuous employment until a maximum of 10 days paid sick leave per year has been accrued. Any days of medical leave with pay that are not taken within the year will be carried over to the beginning of the new year up to a maximum of 10 days. More details and eligibility criteria can be found on the Government of Canada website.
Regardless of jurisdiction, workers may also qualify for Employment Insurance (EI) sickness benefits, which are administered federally. These benefits are available to employees who are unable to work due to medical reasons and meet the eligibility criteria. EI sickness benefits provide 55% of average weekly earnings, up to 695 CAD per week, for a maximum of 26 weeks. To qualify, employees typically need 600 insured hours worked in the 52 weeks prior to illness and must submit a medical certificate. More information can be found on the Government of Canada website.

Maternity Leave

In Canada, Maternity and Parental leave rights are set out through the nationwide Employment Insurance (EI) program, which is applied across all provinces and entitles eligible mothers to take up to 15 weeks of maternity leave with income support. For Federally regulated employees and industries, up to 17 weeks maternity leave can be taken. During this period, eligible employees will receive maternity benefits equal to 55% of their earnings, up to a maximum of 695 CAD per week. To receive this benefit, workers must provide a certificate from a healthcare practitioner confirming the pregnancy. For further guidance and eligibility criteria, refer to the Government of Canada website.

In addition to EI, Nova Scotia sets its own employment standards under the Employment Standards Code, which entitles eligible employees to up to 16 weeks of unpaid pregnancy leave. Maternity leave cannot begin earlier than 16 weeks before the expected date of birth. Employees must provide their employer with at least four weeks’ written notice of their intended leave start date and expected return to work date. An employer can ask for proof of entitlement for pregnancy. More information and eligibility criteria can be found on the Nova Scotia Government website.

If an employee is taking both pregnancy and parental leaves, the employee must take one right after the other and not go back to work between the two leaves.

Paternity Leave

The non birthing partner is entitled to up to 5 consecutive working days of unpaid leave. Employers may choose to ask the employee to complete the Labour Standards Division end of pregnancy form.

Parental Leave

In Canada, Parental leave benefits are available to parents of a newborn or newly adopted child through the nationwide Employment Insurance (EI) program, which is applied across all provinces. Parents can choose between 2 options:

Standard parental benefits – up to 40 weeks leave shared between parents, but one parent cannot take more than 35 weeks, with pay equal to 55% of their earnings, up to a maximum of 695 CAD per week. This leave must be used within 52 weeks of the birth.
Extended parental benefits – up to 69 weeks leave can be shared between parents, but one parent cannot take more than 61 weeks, with pay equal to 33% of their earnings, up to a maximum of 417 CAD per week. This leave must be used within 78 weeks of the birth.

The Parental leave period does not have to be taken consecutively but must be within the above mentioned timeframe. Further information and eligibility criteria can be found on the Government of Canada website.

In addition to EI, each individual province can set their own set of employment standards that determine the full available leave entitlements for parents. In Nova Scotia, eligible employees are entitled to up to 77 weeks of unpaid parental leave to care for a newborn or newly adopted child. This leave must be used within 18 months after the child arrives home. Additional information can be found on the Nova Scotia Government website.

Other Leave

Bereavement Leave

This leave is in place for workers whose family member has died. There are two support systems; the system that applies depends on if the worker falls under the provincial sector or the federally regulated sector:

Workers regulated under the Nova Scotia Labour Standards Code can take unpaid leave of up to 5 working days in a row if their spouse, parent, guardian, child, grandparent, grandchild, sibling, in-law parents, in-law child and in-law sibling.

Employees must give their employers as much notice as possible that they will take this leave.

Federally regulated workers under the Canada Labour Code are entitled to up to 10 days of job protected bereavement leave following the death of an immediate family member. This leave can be taken within 6 weeks of the death. The first 3 days of this leave will be paid if the worker has completed 3 months of continuous employment.

Family Responsibility Leave

In Nova Scotia, employees are entitled to receive up to 3 days of unpaid leave each year to care for an ill parent, child, or family member. These three days can also be used for medical, dental, or other similar appointments for the employee or the employee family member

Additional leave for family matters might be available under the Employment Insurance regulations, based on eligibility.

Compassionate Care Leave

This leave is in place for workers who need to care for seriously ill family members with a significant risk of death. There are two support systems in place which can both be applied to workers:

Under the Nova Scotia’s Labour Standard Code, eligible employees who have been employed for at least 3 months can take up to 26 weeks of unpaid leave to care for seriously ill family members (or a person like family). A qualified medical practitioner must issue a medical certificate stating that the employee’s family member has a serious medical condition with a significant risk of death within twenty-six weeks. Employees who need to take compassionate care leave must give their employer as much notice as possible before taking the leave. An employer can ask in writing for a copy of the medical certificate.
Under Canada’s Federal Employment Insurance (EI), eligible employees who have at least 600 insured hours of work in the 52 weeks before the start of the claim or since the start of their last claim (whichever is shorter) is entitled to caregiving leave of up to 26 weeks. There might also be eligibility for income support equal to 55% of earnings, up to a maximum of 695 CAD per week.

Serious Illness or Injury Leave

This leave is in place for workers who need to take time off for leave due to serious illness or injury. There are two support systems in place which can both be applied to workers:

Under the Nova Scotia Labour Standard Code, eligible employees who are suffering from a serious injury or illness may be entitled to up to 27 weeks of unpaid leave within a 52-week period. This leave may be broken up into multiple periods, however the periods must be at least one week in length. To be eligible, workers must have been employed for at least 3 months.  Employees must let the employer know in writing as soon as possible of their intention to take this leave.
Under Canada’s Federal Employment Insurance (EI), eligible employees who have at least 600 insured hours of work in the 52 weeks before the start of the claim or since the start of their last claim (whichever is shorter) is entitled to sickness leave of up to 26 weeks. There might also be eligibility for income support equal to 55% of earnings, up to a maximum of 695 CAD per week.

Critical Illness Leave

In Nova Scotia, employees have the right to take unpaid Critical Illness Leave to provide care and support for a critically ill family members. The length of leave and eligibility depends on the age of the ill family member:

Employees can take up to 37 weeks of unpaid leave within a 52 week period to provide care or support to a critically ill child under 18 years old.
Employees can take up to 16 weeks of unpaid leave within a 52 week period to provide care or support to a critically ill adult.

To be eligible, for this leave, employees must have worked for the same employer for at least 3 months. The leave can be broken up into several periods of at least one week in duration during this time frame. The 52-week time frame begins on the first day of the week in which the person became critically ill. A qualified medical practitioner must issue a medical certificate stating that the person has a critical illness and the period of time for which the child needs care.

Additional leave, and financial support, might be available under the Employment Insurance regulations, based on eligibility.

Emergency Leave

Employees are entitled to an unpaid Emergency Leave if they are unable to perform their work because of an emergency declared under the Emergency Management Act, or by order of a medical officer under the Health Protection Act, or an emergency declared under the Emergencies Act. Employees can also use this leave to care for a family member who is affected by one of the emergency situations noted above and the employee is the only person who can reasonably care for the family member.

Additional Leave

Under the Canada Labour Code and Nova Scotia Labour Standard Code other types of leave are also regulated including Reservist Leave, Jury Leave, Domestic Violence Leave, Crime Related Child Death or Disappearance Leave and Citizenship Leave.

Termination Process

The termination process in Nova Scotia is based on the regulations outlined in the Labour Standards Code.

For an employee with less than ten years service, the employer does not need a reason to end the employment, but the employer may be required to provide the employee with written notice or pay in lieu of notice. An employer can also end employment without notice or pay in lieu of notice when an employee has been guilty of wilful misconduct or disobedience or neglect of duty that has not been condoned by the employer.

For an employee with 10 years or more service, they cannot be fired or suspended without good reason or just cause. To justify these decisions, the employer might need to show that they had made their expectations clear to the employee, warned them to change behaviour, given them a reasonable chance to change behaviour and made it clear that not improving behaviour could lead to being fired.

Notice Period

Notice should be given in writing or payment in lieu of notice can be given. The length of the required notice period is determined by the employee’s length of service.

Notice by the Employer:

Less than 3 months of service = not notice required
3 months to 2 years of service = 1 week’s notice
2 years to 5 years of service = 2 week’s notice
5 years to 10 years of service = 4  week’s notice
10+ years of service = 8 weeks’ notice

Notice by the Employee:

Less than 3 months of service = not notice required
3 months to 2 years of service = 1 week’s notice
2+ years of service = 2 weeks’ notice

Severance Pay

Nova Scotia regulations typically does not require severance payout as long as notice periods and payment have been followed.

Probation Period

The first 3 months of employment is generally considered to be a probationary period. During this time, no notice is required to be given upon termination or resignation.

This leave is in place for workers who need to care for a critically ill child or adult family member, regardless of whether they are at risk of death. There are two support systems in place which can both be applied to workers:
Under the Ontario Employment Standards Act, eligible employees who have been employed by their employer for at least six consecutive months can take unpaid critical illness job-protected leave of up to 37 weeks in relation to a critically ill minor child, or 17 weeks in relation to a critically ill adult within a 52-week period. Employees must give their employer a qualified health practitioner issued certificate stating stating who is ill and the period that support will be required. Whilst this leave is unpaid, workers might still be eligible to receive income support under the EI.
Under Canada’s Federal Employment Insurance (EI), eligible employees who have at least 600 insured hours of work in the 52 weeks before the start of the claim or since the start of their last claim (whichever is shorter) is entitled to caregiving leave of either 35 weeks to care for a child under 18 or 35 weeks to care for an adult family member. There might also be eligibility for income support equal to 55% of earnings, up to a maximum of 695 CAD per week.
Additional Leave
Under the Canada Labour Code and Ontario Employments Standards Act other types of leave are also regulated including Declared Emergency Leave, Reservist Leave, Jury Leave, Domestic Violence Leave and Death or Disappearance of a Child Leave.

termination.termination_process:
The termination process in Ontario is outlined under the Employment Standards Act. Generally, an employer can terminate the employment of an employee who has been employed continuously for three months or more if the employer has given the employee proper written notice or termination pay in lieu of the notice period.
The ESA does not require an employer to give an employee a reason why their employment is being terminated. When dismissing workers due to reasons of redundancy, insolvency or bankruptcy additional regulations might apply depending on the number of workers who are impacted.
termination.notice_period:
Where a worker has been employed for at least three months, the following notice period must be given to terminate:

1-3 years of employment: 2 weeks’ notice

6-7 years of employment: 6 weeks’ notice
7-8 years of employment: 7 weeks’ notice

termination.severance_pay: To be eligible for severance pay, an employee must have completed at least five years of employment, or the company has a payroll of over 2.5 million CAD per year or have terminated over 50 employees in the past six months due to all or part of the company closing to receive severance payments. The severance pay calculation is based on the number of completed years of employment and the number of completed months of employment divided by 12 for a year that is not completed. The maximum amount of severance pay required to be paid under the ESA is 26 weeks.
termination.probation_period: Probation period in Ontario for a permanent employee is generally set at a minimum of 3 months. No notice is required to be given for dismissal during this period.

data.minimum_wage:
The minimum wage in Quebec is 16.10 CAD per hour.
The minimum wage rate set for employees of Federally regulated organizations will be the current minimum wage rate specified in the jurisdiction in which the employee performs the work.

payroll.payroll_cycle: An employer has 1 month to remit an employee’s first pay. After this, wages must be paid at regular intervals of no more than 16 days, or 1 month in case of managerial personnel. If pay day falls on a statutory holiday, the wages must be paid on the preceding working day.
payroll.13th_salary: There is no legislation for 13th-month payments in Quebec, Canada.

working_hours.general: Per the Quebec Labour Standards Act, the standard workweek in Quebec for most workers is 8 hours per day, 40 hours per week. However, certain industries have longer working hours in place up to 60 hours per week e.g. security guards.
working_hours.overtime:
Work done above the standard workweek is considered as overtime and must be paid at a rate of 150% of the employee’s regular hourly salary. Workers can ask for time off in lieu of payment of overtime hours.
Certain job types might be exempt from overtime rules, such as many managerial and supervisory positions.

leave.annual_leave_(vacation):
In Quebec, employees are entitled to two consecutive weeks of vacation leave after the first year of employment and three consecutive weeks of leave after five years of employment. However, it is common to offer leave from day 1.
Employees are entitled to vacation pay of 4.00% of the regular salary rate of pay for the first five years of employment and 6.00% of the regular salary rate of pay after five years of employment.
In Quebec, under the Labour Standards Act, employees are entitled to vacation time based on their length of continuous employment with the same employer:
Less than 1 year of service = 1 day leave per full month of uninterrupted service, not exceeding 2 weeks.

1 to 3 years of service = 2 consecutive weeks of vacation.

Above 3 years of employment = 3 consecutive weeks of vacation.
Employees are also entitled to vacation pay based on service length:
For employees with less than 3 years of employment, vacation pay must be at least 4% of the gross wages.
For Employees with 3 or more years of employment, vacation pay must be at least 6% of the gross wages.
The worker must receive his vacation indemnity in a lump sum before they start their vacation or at the time of the current pay covering the period of their vacation.

leave.sick_days:
Sick leave entitlement in Manitoba depends on whether the employee falls under provincial or federal regulation, and whether they qualify for Employment Insurance (EI) sickness benefits.
Under Quebec’s Labour Standards Act, non work related accident or illness leave of up to 2 days paid is available after completing at least 3 months of continuous employment. This leave can also be used for the purpose of family care obligations. Employers may request reasonable verification, such as a medical certificate to support the employee’s need for leave. More information can be found on Quebec’s Government website.
Federally regulated workers are entitled under the Canada Labour Code to receive up to 10 days paid sick leave per year. These 10 days paid sick leave is accrued during the year after an initial 30-day qualifying period of continuous employment has been completed.  Following this qualifying period, workers earn the first 3 days of paid medical leave. Following this, workers earn 1 further day of paid sick leave at the start of each month after completing 1 month of continuous employment until a maximum of 10 days paid sick leave per year has been accrued. Any days of medical leave with pay that are not taken within the year will be carried over to the beginning of the new year up to a maximum of 10 days. More details and eligibility criteria can be found on the Government of Canada website.
Regardless of jurisdiction, workers may also qualify for Employment Insurance (EI) sickness benefits, which are administered federally. These benefits are available to employees who are unable to work due to medical reasons and meet the eligibility criteria. EI sickness benefits provide 55% of average weekly earnings, up to 695 CAD per week, for a maximum of 26 weeks. To qualify, employees typically need 600 insured hours worked in the 52 weeks prior to illness and must submit a medical certificate. More information can be found on the Government of Canada website.
Maternity Leave
In Canada, Maternity and Parental leave rights are set out through the nationwide Employment Insurance (EI) program, which is applied across all provinces and entitles eligible mothers to take up to 15 weeks of maternity leave with income support. For Federally regulated employees and industries, up to 17 weeks maternity leave can be taken. During this period, eligible employees will receive maternity benefits equal to 55% of their earnings, up to a maximum of 695 CAD per week. To receive this benefit, workers must provide a certificate from a healthcare practitioner confirming the pregnancy. For further guidance and eligibility criteria, refer to the Government of Canada website.
In addition to EI, Quebec sets its own employment standards under the Labour Standards Act, which entitles eligible employees to up to 18 continuous weeks of unpaid maternity leave. To qualify, an employee must have worked for the same employer for at least seven consecutive months before the expected date of delivery. Maternity leave can begin as of the 16th week before the expected date of birth, and it must end no later than 20 weeks after the birth. Employees must provide their employer with at least 3 weeks’ written notice of their intended leave start date and a medical certificate confirming the pregnancy and expected due date. More information and eligibility criteria can be found on the Quebec Government website.
Following the completion of the maternity benefits, mothers can go on to take Parental Leave.
Paternity Leave
Upon the adoption or birth of a child, a leave of 5 continuous weeks without pay is provided for the parent who did not give birth. They are entitled to this leave regardless of the length of their uninterrupted service. The leave may begin as of the week of the child’s birth and end no later than 78 weeks after the child’s birth.  The notice of leave must be given to their employer at least 3 weeks before they go on leave.
Following the completion of the paternity benefits, additional leave can be taken through Parental Leave.
Five Days of Leave
Both parents (biological or adoptive) may be absent from work for 5 days, the first 2 days of which are paid, for the birth of a child, the adoption of a child or the termination of a pregnancy that occurs as of the 20th week. This right to be absent from work applies to all workers, regardless of the length of their uninterrupted service. It must be taken within 15 days of the child’s birth, the child’s arrival in the home or the termination of pregnancy.
The parent is not entitled to the 5-day leave if they have already started Maternity or Paternity leave. Additional information can be found on the Quebec Government website.
Parental Leave
In Canada, Parental leave benefits are available to parents of a newborn or newly adopted child through the nationwide Employment Insurance (EI) program, which is applied across all provinces. Parents can choose between 2 options:
Standard parental benefits – up to 40 weeks leave shared between parents, but one parent cannot take more than 35 weeks, with pay equal to 55% of their earnings, up to a maximum of 695 CAD per week. This leave must be used within 52 weeks of the birth.
Extended parental benefits – up to 69 weeks leave can be shared between parents, but one parent cannot take more than 61 weeks, with pay equal to 33% of their earnings, up to a maximum of 417 CAD per week. This leave must be used within 78 weeks of the birth.
The Parental leave period does not have to be taken consecutively but must be within the above mentioned timeframe. Further information and eligibility criteria can be found on the Government of Canada website.
In addition to EI, each individual province can set their own set of employment standards that determine the full available leave entitlements for parents. In Quebec, eligible employees are entitled to up to 65 weeks of unpaid parental leave to care for a newborn or newly adopted child. Employees must provide at least 3 weeks’ written notice before starting parental leave and must also give 3 weeks’ written notice before returning to work. Additional information can be found on the Quebec Government website.
leave.other_leave:
Bereavement Leave
This leave is in place for workers whose family member has died. There are two support systems; the system that applies depends on if the worker falls under the provincial sector or the federally regulated sector:
Workers regulated under the Quebec Labour Standards Act are entitled to 5 days of leave (including 2 days with pay) for the death or preparation of the funeral. This right to be absent from work applies to all workers, regardless of the length of their uninterrupted service.
Federally regulated workers under the Canada Labour Code are entitled to up to 10 days of job protected bereavement leave following the death of an immediate family member. This leave can be taken within 6 weeks of the death. The first 3 days of this leave will be paid if the worker has completed 3 months of continuous employment.
Family Leave
In Quebec, employees have the right to take up to 10 days leave per calendar year to fulfil family or parental obligations. For workers with at least 3 months of uninterrupted service, the first 2 days of absence are with pay. Unused days do not carryover into the next calendar year. These days may not be taken for personal reasons e.g. a worker cannot take these days to go and sign papers at a notary’s office.
Extended Absence is in place for the following reasons:
up to 16 weeks over a 12-month period if the worker must stay with a family member or a person for whom they are a natural caregiver and who has a serious illness or had a serious accident.
up to 27 weeks over a 12-month period if the person who is seriously ill has a life-threatening illness.
up to 36 weeks over a12-month period if their minor child is seriously ill or had a serious accident. The absence may be extended for a total of 104 weeks if their minor child has a serious, life-threatening illness, as attested by a medical certificate.
Additional leave for family matters might be available under the Employment Insurance regulations, based on eligibility.
Wedding Leave
Under the Quebec Labour Standards Act, on the day of a workers’ own wedding or civil union, they may be absent from work with pay.
A worker may also be absent from work for one day without pay, for the wedding or civil union of their child, a parent, a sibling or their spouse’s child.
Workers must advise their employer of their absence at least one week in advance.
Additional Leave
Under the Canada Labour Code and Quebec Labour Standards Act other types of leave are also regulated including Reservist Leave, Jury Leave, Suicide of a Loved One Leave and Disappearance of a Child Leave.

termination.termination_process:

Employers can terminate a worker’s employment when they no longer need their services for reasons including economic reasons including financial difficulties, organizational reasons including restructuring of the company or reorganization of duties, and technical reasons, such as technological innovations.
If 10 or more workers are dismissed over a period of 2 consecutive months, this might be considered as a Collective Dismissal, which might require additional process, notice and payout.
When terminating, employers must give written notice. If this is not correctly provided, the worker could be entitled to an monetary indemnity equal to the regular wages the worker would have earned between the date on which the notice should have been provided and the termination of their employment.

10 years or more service = 8 weeks notice
